Have you heard about Interact Club, a fun, dynamic, hands-on service club for youth 12-18 in Cooperation with Rotary International?

According to Cindy Igoe, SJ-BH Rotary Member & Interact Advisor, kids run the clubs with a president, vice president, secretary, treasurer, community service, fundraising, PR, membership, mentoring, and international directors, and project leads. The kids arrange for speakers and choose what projects they will work on in the community and internationally. Rotary International requires Interact Clubs to do one community service project and one international project each year.

Interact involvement helps with community service on college applications and builds self-confidence and self-esteem. It’s also a great way for parents to be involved with their kid’s activities.

Learn more about Interact and how you can get involved at this link:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PH5Jn9Im9IRg00ATHccSk1ycuhjscRnu7lFKVgXCwPg/edit?usp=sharing

2020 KIA Art News
Exciting news from the Watervliet Art Department: Accepted entries were announced today for the Kalamazoo Institute of Arts High School Area Show. This prestigious juried competition draws over 300 entries from nine counties around Southwest Michigan.

Congratulations go out to Braidyn Buskirk and Carlos Gomez Cruz whose ceramic pieces were accepted into the show. In addition, Mercedes Tingue had two pieces accepted into the show. One is a colored pencil portrait of her dog Chloe, the other, a mixed media painting which focuses on climate change and the plight of koalas in Australia.

Unfortunately, because of the recent events regarding COVID-19, the artwork will not be dropped-off or installed in the gallery this year, nor will there be an opening reception. On the bright side, the Kalamazoo Institute of Arts will create a non-traditional, online exhibit of all the accepted artwork. They will also be announcing scholarship award winners virtually.

Way to represent Watervliet!

RUMOR CONTROL MOMENT

There is a rumor floating around that the "Superintendent of Watervliet Schools has the Coronavirus".

That rumor is false.

Mr. Seager and his wife were at a concert on March 8th where the performer was, some days later, determined to have COVID-19. However, Mr. Seager and his wife were told by BCHD they did not qualify for testing at 10-days without symptoms and they sheltered-in-place for an additional 5-days, never having symptoms.

While the event drives home the importance of following social-distancing recommendations, it also brings to light how vulnerable all of us are, in spite of precautions.

Mr. Seager and his wife are in good health and are not suffering from COVID-19.

Attention WPS Families:

Due to excessive illness, all Watervliet Public Schools will be closed on Wednesday, February 5, 2020. This closing includes all off-campus activities during the regular school day. No buses will be run to or between programs tomorrow.

If you or you child are experiencing any flu-like symptoms, please stay away from the school, seek medical attention, and take care of your health by getting plenty of rest, staying hydrated, following proper nutrition, and using good hygiene such as regular hand-washing.

Our goal now is to get our school community healthy, back to school and ready to learn! Please take a look at these resources from the Centers for Disease Control for information about what to do to fight the flu.

Thank you for your cooperation,

Ric Seager

Superintendent of Schools
